('“The deepest parts of the ocean are totally unknown to us,” admits', 70)
('Professor Aronnax early in this novel. “What goes on in those distant', 71)
('depths? What creatures inhabit, or could inhabit, those regions twelve', 72)
('or fifteen miles beneath the surface of the water? It’s almost beyond', 73)
('conjecture.”', 74)
('Jules Verne (1828-1905) published the French equivalents of these', 75)
('words in 1869, and little has changed since. 126 years later, a Time', 76)
('cover story on deep-sea exploration made much the same admission: “We', 77)
('know more about Mars than we know about the oceans.” This reality', 78)
('begins to explain the dark power and otherworldly fascination of', 79)
('Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Seas.', 80)
('Born in the French river town of Nantes, Verne had a lifelong passion', 81)
('for the sea. First as a Paris stockbroker, later as a celebrated', 82)
('author and yachtsman, he went on frequent voyages—to Britain, America,', 83)
('the Mediterranean. But the specific stimulus for this novel was an', 84)
('1865 fan letter from a fellow writer, Madame George Sand. She praised', 85)
('Verne’s two early novels Five Weeks in a Balloon (1863) and Journey to', 86)
('the Center of the Earth (1864), then added: “Soon I hope you’ll take', 87)
('us into the ocean depths, your characters traveling in diving', 88)
('equipment perfected by your science and your imagination.” Thus', 89)
('inspired, Verne created one of literature’s great rebels, a freedom', 90)
('fighter who plunged beneath the waves to wage a unique form of', 91)
('guerilla warfare.', 92)
('Initially, Verne’s narrative was influenced by the 1863 uprising of', 93)
('Poland against Tsarist Russia. The Poles were quashed with a violence', 94)
('that appalled not only Verne but all Europe. As originally conceived,', 95)
('Verne’s Captain Nemo was a Polish nobleman whose entire family had', 96)
('been slaughtered by Russian troops. Nemo builds a fabulous futuristic', 97)
('submarine, the Nautilus, then conducts an underwater campaign of', 98)
('vengeance against his imperialist oppressor.', 99)
('But in the 1860s France had to treat the Tsar as an ally, and Verne’s', 100)
('publisher Pierre Hetzel pronounced the book unprintable. Verne', 101)
('reworked its political content, devising new nationalities for Nemo', 102)
('and his great enemy—information revealed only in a later novel, The', 103)
('Mysterious Island (1875); in the present work Nemo’s background', 104)
('remains a dark secret. In all, the novel had a difficult', 105)
('gestation. Verne and Hetzel were in constant conflict and the book', 106)
('went through multiple drafts, struggles reflected in its several', 107)
('working titles over the period 1865-69: early on, it was variously', 108)
('called Voyage Under the Waters, Twenty-five Thousand Leagues Under the', 109)
('Waters, Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Waters, and A Thousand', 110)
('Leagues Under the Oceans.', 111)
('Verne is often dubbed, in Isaac Asimov’s phrase, “the world’s first', 112)
('science-fiction writer.” And it’s true, many of his sixty-odd books do', 113)
('anticipate future events and technologies: From the Earth to the Moon', 114)
('(1865) and Hector Servadac (1877) deal in space travel, while Journey', 115)
('to the Center of the Earth features travel to the earth’s core. But', 116)
('with Verne the operative word is “travel,” and some of his best-known', 117)
('titles don’t really qualify as sci-fi: Around the World in Eighty Days', 118)
('(1872) and Michael Strogoff (1876) are closer to “travelogs”—adventure', 119)
('yarns in far-away places.', 120)
('These observations partly apply here. The subtitle of the present book', 121)
('is An Underwater Tour of the World, so in good travelog style, the', 122)
('Nautilus’s exploits supply an episodic story line. Shark attacks,', 123)
('giant squid, cannibals, hurricanes, whale hunts, and other rip-roaring', 124)
('adventures erupt almost at random. Yet this loose structure gives the', 125)
('novel an air of documentary realism. What’s more, Verne adds backbone', 126)
('to the action by developing three recurring motifs: the deepening', 127)
('mystery of Nemo’s past life and future intentions, the mounting', 128)
('tension between Nemo and hot-tempered harpooner Ned Land, and Ned’s', 129)
('ongoing schemes to escape from the Nautilus. These unifying threads', 130)
('tighten the narrative and accelerate its momentum.', 131)
('Other subtleties occur inside each episode, the textures sparkling', 132)
('with wit, information, and insight. Verne regards the sea from many', 133)
('angles: in the domain of marine biology, he gives us thumbnail', 134)
('sketches of fish, seashells, coral, sometimes in great catalogs that', 135)
('swirl past like musical cascades; in the realm of geology, he studies', 136)
('volcanoes literally inside and out; in the world of commerce, he', 137)
('celebrates the high-energy entrepreneurs who lay the Atlantic Cable or', 138)
('dig the Suez Canal. And Verne’s marine engineering proves especially', 139)
('authoritative. His specifications for an open-sea submarine and a', 140)
('self-contained diving suit were decades before their time, yet modern', 141)
('technology bears them out triumphantly.', 142)
('True, today’s scientists know a few things he didn’t: the South Pole', 143)
('isn’t at the water’s edge but far inland; sharks don’t flip over', 144)
('before attacking; giant squid sport ten tentacles not eight; sperm', 145)
('whales don’t prey on their whalebone cousins. This notwithstanding,', 146)
('Verne furnishes the most evocative portrayal of the ocean depths', 147)
('before the arrival of Jacques Cousteau and technicolor film.', 148)
('Lastly the book has stature as a novel of character. Even the', 149)
('supporting cast is shrewdly drawn: Professor Aronnax, the career', 150)
('scientist caught in an ethical conflict; Conseil, the compulsive', 151)
('classifier who supplies humorous tag lines for Verne’s fast facts; the', 152)
('harpooner Ned Land, a creature of constant appetites, man as heroic', 153)
('animal.', 154)
('But much of the novel’s brooding power comes from Captain', 155)
('Nemo. Inventor, musician, Renaissance genius, he’s a trail-blazing', 156)
('creation, the prototype not only for countless renegade scientists in', 157)
('popular fiction, but even for such varied figures as Sherlock Holmes', 158)
('or Wolf Larsen. However, Verne gives his hero’s brilliance and', 159)
('benevolence a dark underside—the man’s obsessive hate for his old', 160)
('enemy. This compulsion leads Nemo into ugly contradictions: he’s a', 161)
('fighter for freedom, yet all who board his ship are imprisoned there', 162)
('for good; he works to save lives, both human and animal, yet he', 163)
('himself creates a holocaust; he detests imperialism, yet he lays', 164)
('personal claim to the South Pole. And in this last action he falls', 165)
('into the classic sin of Pride. He’s swiftly punished. The Nautilus', 166)
('nearly perishes in the Antarctic and Nemo sinks into a growing', 167)
('depression.', 168)
('Like Shakespeare’s King Lear he courts death and madness in a great', 169)
('storm, then commits mass murder, collapses in catatonic paralysis, and', 170)
('suicidally runs his ship into the ocean’s most dangerous', 171)
('whirlpool. Hate swallows him whole.', 172)
('For many, then, this book has been a source of fascination, surely one', 173)
('of the most influential novels ever written, an inspiration for such', 174)
('scientists and discoverers as engineer Simon Lake, oceanographer', 175)
('William Beebe, polar traveler Sir Ernest Shackleton. Likewise', 176)
('Dr. Robert D. Ballard, finder of the sunken Titanic, confesses that', 177)
('this was his favorite book as a teenager, and Cousteau himself, most', 178)
('renowned of marine explorers, called it his shipboard bible.', 179)
('The present translation is a faithful yet communicative rendering of', 180)
('the original French texts published in Paris by J. Hetzel et Cie.—the', 181)
('hardcover first edition issued in the autumn of 1871, collated with', 182)
('the softcover editions of the First and Second Parts issued separately', 183)
('in the autumn of 1869 and the summer of 1870. Although prior English', 184)
('versions have often been heavily abridged, this new translation is', 185)
('complete to the smallest substantive detail.', 186)
('Because, as that Time cover story suggests, we still haven’t caught up', 187)
('with Verne. Even in our era of satellite dishes and video games, the', 188)
('seas keep their secrets. We’ve seen progress in sonar, torpedoes, and', 189)
('other belligerent machinery, but sailors and scientists—to say nothing', 190)
('of tourists—have yet to voyage in a submarine with the luxury and', 191)
('efficiency of the Nautilus.', 192)

('CHAPTER 1', 215)
('A Runaway Reef', 216)
('THE YEAR 1866 was marked by a bizarre development, an unexplained and', 217)
('downright inexplicable phenomenon that surely no one has', 218)
('forgotten. Without getting into those rumors that upset civilians in', 219)
('the seaports and deranged the public mind even far inland, it must be', 220)
('said that professional seamen were especially alarmed. Traders,', 221)
('shipowners, captains of vessels, skippers, and master mariners from', 222)
('Europe and America, naval officers from every country, and at their', 223)
('heels the various national governments on these two continents, were', 224)
('all extremely disturbed by the business.', 225)
('In essence, over a period of time several ships had encountered “an', 226)
('enormous thing” at sea, a long spindle-shaped object, sometimes giving', 227)
('off a phosphorescent glow, infinitely bigger and faster than any', 228)
('whale.', 229)
('The relevant data on this apparition, as recorded in various logbooks,', 230)
('agreed pretty closely as to the structure of the object or creature in', 231)
('question, its unprecedented speed of movement, its startling', 232)
('locomotive power, and the unique vitality with which it seemed to be', 233)
('gifted. If it was a cetacean, it exceeded in bulk any whale previously', 234)
('classified by science. No naturalist, neither Cuvier nor Lacépède,', 235)
('neither Professor Dumeril nor Professor de Quatrefages, would have', 236)
('accepted the existence of such a monster sight unseen—specifically,', 237)
('unseen by their own scientific eyes.', 238)
('Striking an average of observations taken at different times—rejecting', 239)
('those timid estimates that gave the object a length of 200 feet, and', 240)
('ignoring those exaggerated views that saw it as a mile wide and three', 241)
('long—you could still assert that this phenomenal creature greatly', 242)
('exceeded the dimensions of anything then known to ichthyologists, if', 243)
('it existed at all.', 244)
('Now then, it did exist, this was an undeniable fact; and since the', 245)
('human mind dotes on objects of wonder, you can understand the', 246)
('worldwide excitement caused by this unearthly apparition. As for', 247)
('relegating it to the realm of fiction, that charge had to be dropped.', 248)
('In essence, on July 20, 1866, the steamer Governor Higginson, from the', 249)
('Calcutta & Burnach Steam Navigation Co., encountered this moving mass', 250)
('five miles off the eastern shores of Australia.', 251)
('Captain Baker at first thought he was in the presence of an unknown', 252)
('reef; he was even about to fix its exact position when two waterspouts', 253)
('shot out of this inexplicable object and sprang hissing into the air', 254)
('some 150 feet. So, unless this reef was subject to the intermittent', 255)
('eruptions of a geyser, the Governor Higginson had fair and honest', 256)
('dealings with some aquatic mammal, until then unknown, that could', 257)
('spurt from its blowholes waterspouts mixed with air and steam.', 258)
('Similar events were likewise observed in Pacific seas, on July 23 of', 259)
('the same year, by the Christopher Columbus from the West India &', 260)
('Pacific Steam Navigation Co. Consequently, this extraordinary cetacean', 261)
('could transfer itself from one locality to another with startling', 262)
('swiftness, since within an interval of just three days, the Governor', 263)
('Higginson and the Christopher Columbus had observed it at two', 264)
('positions on the charts separated by a distance of more than 700', 265)
('nautical leagues.', 266)
('Fifteen days later and 2,000 leagues farther, the Helvetia from the', 267)
('Compagnie Nationale and the Shannon from the Royal Mail line, running', 268)
('on opposite tacks in that part of the Atlantic lying between the', 269)
('United States and Europe, respectively signaled each other that the', 270)
('monster had been sighted in latitude 42 degrees 15’ north and', 271)
('longitude 60 degrees 35’ west of the meridian of Greenwich. From their', 272)
('simultaneous observations, they were able to estimate the mammal’s', 273)
('minimum length at more than 350 English feet;* this was because both', 274)
('the Shannon and the Helvetia were of smaller dimensions, although each', 275)
('measured 100 meters stem to stern. Now then, the biggest whales, those', 276)
('rorqual whales that frequent the waterways of the Aleutian Islands,', 277)
('have never exceeded a length of 56 meters—if they reach even that.', 278)
('*Author’s Note: About 106 meters. An English foot is only 30.4', 279)
('centimeters.', 280)
('One after another, reports arrived that would profoundly affect public', 281)
('opinion: new observations taken by the transatlantic liner Pereire,', 282)
('the Inman line’s Etna running afoul of the monster, an official report', 283)
('drawn up by officers on the French frigate Normandy, dead-earnest', 284)
('reckonings obtained by the general staff of Commodore Fitz-James', 285)
('aboard the Lord Clyde. In lighthearted countries, people joked about', 286)
('this phenomenon, but such serious, practical countries as England,', 287)
('America, and Germany were deeply concerned.', 288)
('In every big city the monster was the latest rage; they sang about it', 289)
('in the coffee houses, they ridiculed it in the newspapers, they', 290)
('dramatized it in the theaters. The tabloids found it a fine', 291)
('opportunity for hatching all sorts of hoaxes. In those newspapers', 292)
('short of copy, you saw the reappearance of every gigantic imaginary', 293)
('creature, from “Moby Dick,” that dreadful white whale from the High', 294)
('Arctic regions, to the stupendous kraken whose tentacles could entwine', 295)
('a 500-ton craft and drag it into the ocean depths. They even reprinted', 296)
('reports from ancient times: the views of Aristotle and Pliny accepting', 297)
('the existence of such monsters, then the Norwegian stories of Bishop', 298)
('Pontoppidan, the narratives of Paul Egede, and finally the reports of', 299)
('Captain Harrington—whose good faith is above suspicion—in which he', 300)
('claims he saw, while aboard the Castilian in 1857, one of those', 301)
('enormous serpents that, until then, had frequented only the seas of', 302)
('France’s old extremist newspaper, The Constitutionalist.', 303)
('An interminable debate then broke out between believers and skeptics', 304)
('in the scholarly societies and scientific journals. The “monster', 305)
('question” inflamed all minds. During this memorable campaign,', 306)
('journalists making a profession of science battled with those making a', 307)
('profession of wit, spilling waves of ink and some of them even two or', 308)
('three drops of blood, since they went from sea serpents to the most', 309)
('offensive personal remarks.', 310)
('For six months the war seesawed. With inexhaustible zest, the popular', 311)
('press took potshots at feature articles from the Geographic Institute', 312)
('of Brazil, the Royal Academy of Science in Berlin, the British', 313)
('Association, the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., at', 314)
('discussions in The Indian Archipelago, in Cosmos published by Father', 315)
('Moigno, in Petermann’s Mittheilungen,* and at scientific chronicles in', 316)
('the great French and foreign newspapers. When the monster’s detractors', 317)
('cited a saying by the botanist Linnaeus that “nature doesn’t make', 318)
('leaps,” witty writers in the popular periodicals parodied it,', 319)
('maintaining in essence that “nature doesn’t make lunatics,” and', 320)
('ordering their contemporaries never to give the lie to nature by', 321)
('believing in krakens, sea serpents, “Moby Dicks,” and other all-out', 322)
('efforts from drunken seamen. Finally, in a much-feared satirical', 323)
('journal, an article by its most popular columnist finished off the', 324)
('monster for good, spurning it in the style of Hippolytus repulsing the', 325)
('amorous advances of his stepmother Phaedra, and giving the creature', 326)
('its quietus amid a universal burst of laughter. Wit had defeated', 327)
('science.', 328)
('*German: “Bulletin.” Ed.', 329)
('During the first months of the year 1867, the question seemed to be', 330)
('buried, and it didn’t seem due for resurrection, when new facts were', 331)
('brought to the public’s attention. But now it was no longer an issue', 332)
('of a scientific problem to be solved, but a quite real and serious', 333)
('danger to be avoided. The question took an entirely new turn. The', 334)
('monster again became an islet, rock, or reef, but a runaway reef,', 335)
('unfixed and elusive.', 336)
('On March 5, 1867, the Moravian from the Montreal Ocean Co., lying', 337)
('during the night in latitude 27 degrees 30’ and longitude 72 degrees', 338)
('15’, ran its starboard quarter afoul of a rock marked on no charts of', 339)
('these waterways. Under the combined efforts of wind and 400-horsepower', 340)
('steam, it was traveling at a speed of thirteen knots. Without the high', 341)
('quality of its hull, the Moravian would surely have split open from', 342)
('this collision and gone down together with those 237 passengers it was', 343)
('bringing back from Canada.', 344)
('This accident happened around five o’clock in the morning, just as day', 345)
('was beginning to break. The officers on watch rushed to the craft’s', 346)
('stern. They examined the ocean with the most scrupulous care. They saw', 347)
('nothing except a strong eddy breaking three cable lengths out, as if', 348)
('those sheets of water had been violently churned. The site’s exact', 349)
('bearings were taken, and the Moravian continued on course apparently', 350)
('undamaged. Had it run afoul of an underwater rock or the wreckage of', 351)
('some enormous derelict ship? They were unable to say. But when they', 352)
('examined its undersides in the service yard, they discovered that part', 353)
('of its keel had been smashed.', 354)
('This occurrence, extremely serious in itself, might perhaps have been', 355)
('forgotten like so many others, if three weeks later it hadn’t been', 356)
('reenacted under identical conditions. Only, thanks to the nationality', 357)
('of the ship victimized by this new ramming, and thanks to the', 358)
('reputation of the company to which this ship belonged, the event', 359)
('caused an immense uproar.', 360)
('No one is unaware of the name of that famous English shipowner,', 361)
('Cunard. In 1840 this shrewd industrialist founded a postal service', 362)
('between Liverpool and Halifax, featuring three wooden ships with', 363)
('400-horsepower paddle wheels and a burden of 1,162 metric tons. Eight', 364)
('years later, the company’s assets were increased by four', 365)
('650-horsepower ships at 1,820 metric tons, and in two more years, by', 366)
('two other vessels of still greater power and tonnage. In 1853 the', 367)
('Cunard Co., whose mail-carrying charter had just been renewed,', 368)
('successively added to its assets the Arabia, the Persia, the China,', 369)
('the Scotia, the Java, and the Russia, all ships of top speed and,', 370)
('after the Great Eastern, the biggest ever to plow the seas. So in 1867', 371)
('this company owned twelve ships, eight with paddle wheels and four', 372)
('with propellers.', 373)
('If I give these highly condensed details, it is so everyone can fully', 374)
('understand the importance of this maritime transportation company,', 375)
('known the world over for its shrewd management. No transoceanic', 376)
('navigational undertaking has been conducted with more ability, no', 377)
('business dealings have been crowned with greater success. In', 378)
('twenty-six years Cunard ships have made 2,000 Atlantic crossings', 379)
('without so much as a voyage canceled, a delay recorded, a man, a', 380)
('craft, or even a letter lost. Accordingly, despite strong competition', 381)
('from France, passengers still choose the Cunard line in preference to', 382)
('all others, as can be seen in a recent survey of official', 383)
('documents. Given this, no one will be astonished at the uproar', 384)
('provoked by this accident involving one of its finest steamers.', 385)
('On April 13, 1867, with a smooth sea and a moderate breeze, the Scotia', 386)
('lay in longitude 15 degrees 12’ and latitude 45 degrees 37’. It was', 387)
('traveling at a speed of 13.43 knots under the thrust of its', 388)
('1,000-horsepower engines. Its paddle wheels were churning the sea with', 389)
('perfect steadiness. It was then drawing 6.7 meters of water and', 390)
('displacing 6,624 cubic meters.', 391)
('At 4:17 in the afternoon, during a high tea for passengers gathered in', 392)
('the main lounge, a collision occurred, scarcely noticeable on the', 393)
('whole, affecting the Scotia’s hull in that quarter a little astern of', 394)
('its port paddle wheel.', 395)
('The Scotia hadn’t run afoul of something, it had been fouled, and by a', 396)
('cutting or perforating instrument rather than a blunt one. This', 397)
('encounter seemed so minor that nobody on board would have been', 398)
('disturbed by it, had it not been for the shouts of crewmen in the', 399)
('hold, who climbed on deck yelling:', 400)
('“We’re sinking! We’re sinking!”', 401)
('At first the passengers were quite frightened, but Captain Anderson', 402)
('hastened to reassure them. In fact, there could be no immediate', 403)
('danger. Divided into seven compartments by watertight bulkheads, the', 404)
('Scotia could brave any leak with impunity.', 405)
('Captain Anderson immediately made his way into the hold. He discovered', 406)
('that the fifth compartment had been invaded by the sea, and the speed', 407)
('of this invasion proved that the leak was considerable. Fortunately', 408)
('this compartment didn’t contain the boilers, because their furnaces', 409)
('would have been abruptly extinguished.', 410)
('Captain Anderson called an immediate halt, and one of his sailors', 411)
('dived down to assess the damage. Within moments they had located a', 412)
('hole two meters in width on the steamer’s underside. Such a leak could', 413)
('not be patched, and with its paddle wheels half swamped, the Scotia', 414)
('had no choice but to continue its voyage. By then it lay 300 miles', 415)
('from Cape Clear, and after three days of delay that filled Liverpool', 416)
('with acute anxiety, it entered the company docks.', 417)
('The engineers then proceeded to inspect the Scotia, which had been put', 418)
('in dry dock. They couldn’t believe their eyes. Two and a half meters', 419)
('below its waterline, there gaped a symmetrical gash in the shape of an', 420)
('isosceles triangle. This breach in the sheet iron was so perfectly', 421)
('formed, no punch could have done a cleaner job of it. Consequently, it', 422)
('must have been produced by a perforating tool of uncommon', 423)
('toughness—plus, after being launched with prodigious power and then', 424)
('piercing four centimeters of sheet iron, this tool had needed to', 425)
('withdraw itself by a backward motion truly inexplicable.', 426)
('This was the last straw, and it resulted in arousing public passions', 427)
('all over again. Indeed, from this moment on, any maritime casualty', 428)
('without an established cause was charged to the monster’s', 429)
('account. This outrageous animal had to shoulder responsibility for all', 430)
('derelict vessels, whose numbers are unfortunately considerable, since', 431)
('out of those 3,000 ships whose losses are recorded annually at the', 432)
('marine insurance bureau, the figure for steam or sailing ships', 433)
('supposedly lost with all hands, in the absence of any news, amounts to', 434)
('at least 200!', 435)
('Now then, justly or unjustly, it was the “monster” who stood accused', 436)
('of their disappearance; and since, thanks to it, travel between the', 437)
('various continents had become more and more dangerous, the public', 438)
('spoke up and demanded straight out that, at all cost, the seas be', 439)
('purged of this fearsome cetacean.', 440)
('CHAPTER 2', 441)
('The Pros and Cons', 442)
('DURING THE PERIOD in which these developments were occurring, I had', 443)
('returned from a scientific undertaking organized to explore the', 444)
('Nebraska badlands in the United States. In my capacity as Assistant', 445)
('Professor at the Paris Museum of Natural History, I had been attached', 446)
('to this expedition by the French government. After spending six months', 447)
('in Nebraska, I arrived in New York laden with valuable collections', 448)
('near the end of March. My departure for France was set for early', 449)
('May. In the meantime, then, I was busy classifying my mineralogical,', 450)
('botanical, and zoological treasures when that incident took place with', 451)
('the Scotia.', 452)
('I was perfectly abreast of this question, which was the big news of', 453)
('the day, and how could I not have been? I had read and reread every', 454)
('American and European newspaper without being any farther along. This', 455)
('mystery puzzled me. Finding it impossible to form any views, I drifted', 456)
('from one extreme to the other. Something was out there, that much was', 457)
('certain, and any doubting Thomas was invited to place his finger on', 458)
('the Scotia’s wound.', 459)
('When I arrived in New York, the question was at the boiling point. The', 460)
('hypothesis of a drifting islet or an elusive reef, put forward by', 461)
('people not quite in their right minds, was completely eliminated. And', 462)
('indeed, unless this reef had an engine in its belly, how could it move', 463)
('about with such prodigious speed?', 464)
('Also discredited was the idea of a floating hull or some other', 465)
('enormous wreckage, and again because of this speed of movement.', 466)
('So only two possible solutions to the question were left, creating two', 467)
('very distinct groups of supporters: on one side, those favoring a', 468)
('monster of colossal strength; on the other, those favoring an', 469)
('“underwater boat” of tremendous motor power.', 470)
('Now then, although the latter hypothesis was completely admissible, it', 471)
('couldn’t stand up to inquiries conducted in both the New World and the', 472)
('Old. That a private individual had such a mechanism at his disposal', 473)
('was less than probable. Where and when had he built it, and how could', 474)
('he have built it in secret?', 475)
('Only some government could own such an engine of destruction, and in', 476)
('these disaster-filled times, when men tax their ingenuity to build', 477)
('increasingly powerful aggressive weapons, it was possible that,', 478)
('unknown to the rest of the world, some nation could have been testing', 479)
('such a fearsome machine. The Chassepot rifle led to the torpedo, and', 480)
('the torpedo has led to this underwater battering ram, which in turn', 481)
('will lead to the world putting its foot down. At least I hope it will.', 482)
('But this hypothesis of a war machine collapsed in the face of formal', 483)
('denials from the various governments. Since the public interest was at', 484)
('stake and transoceanic travel was suffering, the sincerity of these', 485)
('governments could not be doubted. Besides, how could the assembly of', 486)
('this underwater boat have escaped public notice? Keeping a secret', 487)
('under such circumstances would be difficult enough for an individual,', 488)
('and certainly impossible for a nation whose every move is under', 489)
('constant surveillance by rival powers.', 490)
('So, after inquiries conducted in England, France, Russia, Prussia,', 491)
('Spain, Italy, America, and even Turkey, the hypothesis of an', 492)
('underwater Monitor was ultimately rejected.', 493)
('And so the monster surfaced again, despite the endless witticisms', 494)
('heaped on it by the popular press, and the human imagination soon got', 495)
('caught up in the most ridiculous ichthyological fantasies.', 496)
('After I arrived in New York, several people did me the honor of', 497)
('consulting me on the phenomenon in question. In France I had published', 498)
('a two-volume work, in quarto, entitled The Mysteries of the Great', 499)
('Ocean Depths. Well received in scholarly circles, this book had', 500)
('established me as a specialist in this pretty obscure field of natural', 501)
('history. My views were in demand. As long as I could deny the reality', 502)
('of the business, I confined myself to a flat “no comment.” But soon,', 503)
('pinned to the wall, I had to explain myself straight out. And in this', 504)
('vein, “the honorable Pierre Aronnax, Professor at the Paris Museum,”', 505)
('was summoned by The New York Herald to formulate his views no matter', 506)
('what.', 507)
('I complied. Since I could no longer hold my tongue, I let it wag. I', 508)
('discussed the question in its every aspect, both political and', 509)
('scientific, and this is an excerpt from the well-padded article I', 510)
('published in the issue of April 30.', 511)
('“Therefore,” I wrote, “after examining these different hypotheses one', 512)
('by one, we are forced, every other supposition having been refuted, to', 513)
('accept the existence of an extremely powerful marine animal.', 514)
('“The deepest parts of the ocean are totally unknown to us. No', 515)
('soundings have been able to reach them. What goes on in those distant', 516)
('depths? What creatures inhabit, or could inhabit, those regions twelve', 517)
('or fifteen miles beneath the surface of the water? What is the', 518)
('constitution of these animals? It’s almost beyond conjecture.', 519)
('“However, the solution to this problem submitted to me can take the', 520)
('form of a choice between two alternatives.', 521)
('“Either we know every variety of creature populating our planet, or we', 522)
('do not.', 523)
('“If we do not know every one of them, if nature still keeps', 524)
('ichthyological secrets from us, nothing is more admissible than to', 525)
('accept the existence of fish or cetaceans of new species or even new', 526)
('genera, animals with a basically ‘cast-iron’ constitution that inhabit', 527)

('level of the ocean for long intervals.', 530)
('“If, on the other hand, we do know every living species, we must look', 531)
('for the animal in question among those marine creatures already', 532)
('cataloged, and in this event I would be inclined to accept the', 533)
('existence of a giant narwhale.', 534)
('“The common narwhale, or sea unicorn, often reaches a length of sixty', 535)
('feet. Increase its dimensions fivefold or even tenfold, then give this', 536)
('cetacean a strength in proportion to its size while enlarging its', 537)
('offensive weapons, and you have the animal we’re looking for. It would', 538)
('have the proportions determined by the officers of the Shannon, the', 539)
('instrument needed to perforate the Scotia, and the power to pierce a', 540)
('steamer’s hull.', 541)
('“In essence, the narwhale is armed with a sort of ivory sword, or', 542)
('lance, as certain naturalists have expressed it. It’s a king-sized', 543)
('tooth as hard as steel. Some of these teeth have been found buried in', 544)
('the bodies of baleen whales, which the narwhale attacks with', 545)

('meters and a width at its base of forty-eight centimeters!', 550)
('“All right then! Imagine this weapon to be ten times stronger and the', 551)

('“This inexplicable phenomenon is thus explained away—unless it’s', 559)

('“the monster.”', 566)
('My article was hotly debated, causing a fine old uproar. It rallied a', 567)

('CHAPTER 3', 640)
('As Master Wishes', 641)

('CHAPTER 4', 825)
('Ned Land', 826)
('COMMANDER FARRAGUT was a good seaman, worthy of the frigate he', 827)
('commanded. His ship and he were one. He was its very soul. On the', 828)
('cetacean question no doubts arose in his mind, and he didn’t allow the', 829)
('animal’s existence to be disputed aboard his vessel. He believed in it', 830)
('as certain pious women believe in the leviathan from the Book of', 831)

('rid the seas of it. The man was a sort of Knight of Rhodes, a', 833)
('latter-day Sir Dieudonné of Gozo, on his way to fight an encounter', 834)
('with the dragon devastating the island. Either Commander Farragut', 835)
('would slay the narwhale, or the narwhale would slay Commander', 836)
('Farragut. No middle of the road for these two.', 837)
('The ship’s officers shared the views of their leader. They could be', 838)

('ocean. Voluntary watches from the crosstrees of the topgallant sail', 841)

('CHAPTER 1', 6647)
('The Indian Ocean', 6648)
('NOW WE BEGIN the second part of this voyage under the seas. The first', 6649)
('ended in that moving scene at the coral cemetery, which left a', 6650)

('In fact, the mystery of that last afternoon when we were locked in', 6666)

('content simply to avoid humanity! His fearsome submersible served not', 6671)
('only his quest for freedom, but also, perhaps, it was used in', 6672)
('lord-knows-what schemes of dreadful revenge.', 6673)
('Right now, nothing is clear to me, I still glimpse only glimmers in', 6674)
('the dark, and I must limit my pen, as it were, to taking dictation', 6675)
('from events.', 6676)
('But nothing binds us to Captain Nemo. He believes that escaping from', 6677)
('the Nautilus is impossible. We are not even constrained by our word of', 6678)

('masquerading under the name “guests” for the sake of everyday', 6680)

('That day, January 21, 1868, the chief officer went at noon to take the', 6701)

('CHAPTER 7', 8785)
('The Mediterranean in Forty-Eight Hours', 8786)
('THE MEDITERRANEAN, your ideal blue sea: to Greeks simply “the sea,” to', 8787)
('Hebrews “the great sea,” to Romans mare nostrum.* Bordered by orange', 8788)
('trees, aloes, cactus, and maritime pine trees, perfumed with the scent', 8789)

('the French historian Michelet, a man is revived by one of the most', 8794)
('invigorating climates in the world.', 8795)

('Captain Nemo’s personal insights were denied me, because that', 8799)
('mystifying individual didn’t appear one single time during our', 8800)

('accomplished in just twenty-four hours times two. Departing from the', 8803)

('Strait of Gibraltar by sunrise on the 18th.', 8805)

('regrets. Here he no longer had the ease of movement and freedom of', 8809)
('maneuver that the oceans allowed him, and his Nautilus felt cramped so', 8810)
('close to the coasts of both Africa and Europe.', 8811)
('Accordingly, our speed was twenty-five miles (that is, twelve', 8812)

('CHAPTER 11', 10162)
('The Sargasso Sea', 10163)
('THE NAUTILUS didn’t change direction. For the time being, then, we had', 10164)
('to set aside any hope of returning to European seas. Captain Nemo kept', 10165)
('his prow pointing south. Where was he taking us? I was afraid to', 10166)
('guess.', 10167)
('That day the Nautilus crossed an odd part of the Atlantic Ocean. No', 10168)
('one is unaware of the existence of that great warm-water current known', 10169)
('by name as the Gulf Stream. After emerging from channels off Florida,', 10170)
('it heads toward Spitzbergen. But before entering the Gulf of Mexico', 10171)
('near latitude 44 degrees north, this current divides into two arms;', 10172)
('its chief arm makes for the shores of Ireland and Norway while the', 10173)
('second flexes southward at the level of the Azores; then it hits the', 10174)
('coast of Africa, sweeps in a long oval, and returns to the Caribbean', 10175)

('CHAPTER 15', 11666)
('Accident or Incident?', 11667)
('THE NEXT DAY, March 22, at six o’clock in the morning, preparations', 11668)
('for departure began. The last gleams of twilight were melting into', 11669)
('night. The cold was brisk. The constellations were glittering with', 11670)
('startling intensity. The wonderful Southern Cross, polar star of the', 11671)
('Antarctic regions, twinkled at its zenith.', 11672)
('The thermometer marked -12 degrees centigrade, and a fresh breeze left', 11673)
('a sharp nip in the air. Ice floes were increasing over the open', 11674)
('water. The sea was starting to congeal everywhere. Numerous blackish', 11675)
('patches were spreading over its surface, announcing the imminent', 11676)
('formation of fresh ice. Obviously this southernmost basin froze over', 11677)
('during its six-month winter and became utterly inaccessible. What', 11678)
('happened to the whales during this period? No doubt they went beneath', 11679)
('the Ice Bank to find more feasible seas. As for seals and walruses,', 11680)
('they were accustomed to living in the harshest climates and stayed on', 11681)
('in these icy waterways. These animals know by instinct how to gouge', 11682)
('holes in the ice fields and keep them continually open; they go to', 11683)
('these holes to breathe. Once the birds have migrated northward to', 11684)
('escape the cold, these marine mammals remain as sole lords of the', 11685)
('polar continent.', 11686)
('Meanwhile the ballast tanks filled with water and the Nautilus sank', 11687)
('slowly. At a depth of 1,000 feet, it stopped. Its propeller churned', 11688)
('the waves and it headed due north at a speed of fifteen miles per', 11689)
('hour. Near the afternoon it was already cruising under the immense', 11690)
('frozen carapace of the Ice Bank.', 11691)
('As a precaution, the panels in the lounge stayed closed, because the', 11692)
('Nautilus’s hull could run afoul of some submerged block of ice. So I', 11693)
('spent the day putting my notes into final form. My mind was completely', 11694)
('wrapped up in my memories of the pole. We had reached that', 11695)
('inaccessible spot without facing exhaustion or danger, as if our', 11696)
('seagoing passenger carriage had glided there on railroad tracks. And', 11697)
('now we had actually started our return journey. Did it still have', 11698)
('comparable surprises in store for me? I felt sure it did, so', 11699)
('inexhaustible is this series of underwater wonders! As it was, in the', 11700)
('five and a half months since fate had brought us on board, we had', 11701)
('cleared 14,000 leagues, and over this track longer than the earth’s', 11702)
('equator, so many fascinating or frightening incidents had beguiled our', 11703)
('voyage: that hunting trip in the Crespo forests, our running aground', 11704)
('in the Torres Strait, the coral cemetery, the pearl fisheries of', 11705)
('Ceylon, the Arabic tunnel, the fires of Santorini, those millions in', 11706)
('the Bay of Vigo, Atlantis, the South Pole! During the night all these', 11707)
('memories crossed over from one dream to the next, not giving my brain', 11708)
('a moment’s rest.', 11709)
('At three o’clock in the morning, I was awakened by a violent', 11710)
('collision. I sat up in bed, listening in the darkness, and then was', 11711)
('suddenly hurled into the middle of my stateroom. Apparently the', 11712)
('Nautilus had gone aground, then heeled over sharply.', 11713)
('Leaning against the walls, I dragged myself down the gangways to the', 11714)
('lounge, whose ceiling lights were on. The furniture had been knocked', 11715)
('over. Fortunately the glass cases were solidly secured at the base and', 11716)
('had stood fast. Since we were no longer vertical, the starboard', 11717)
('pictures were glued to the tapestries, while those to port had their', 11718)
('lower edges hanging a foot away from the wall. So the Nautilus was', 11719)
('lying on its starboard side, completely stationary to boot.', 11720)
('In its interior I heard the sound of footsteps and muffled voices. But', 11721)
('Captain Nemo didn’t appear. Just as I was about to leave the lounge,', 11722)

('CHAPTER 19', 12946)
('The Gulf Stream', 12947)
('THIS DREADFUL SCENE on April 20 none of us will ever be able to', 12948)
('forget. I wrote it up in a state of intense excitement. Later I', 12949)
('reviewed my narrative. I read it to Conseil and the Canadian. They', 12950)

('aboard. And what a way to die! Smashed, strangled, crushed by the', 12956)

('Captain Nemo reentered his stateroom, and I saw no more of him for a', 12969)

('to judge from this ship whose soul he was, which reflected his every', 12971)

('struggle, from this sea that had devoured one of its own!', 12976)
('Ten days went by in this way. It was only on May 1 that the Nautilus', 12977)
('openly resumed its northbound course, after raising the Bahamas at the', 12978)
('mouth of Old Bahama Channel. We then went with the current of the', 12979)
('sea’s greatest river, which has its own banks, fish, and', 12980)
('temperature. I mean the Gulf Stream.', 12981)
('It is indeed a river that runs independently through the middle of the', 12982)
('Atlantic, its waters never mixing with the ocean’s waters. It’s a', 12983)
('salty river, saltier than the sea surrounding it. Its average depth is', 12984)
('3,000 feet, its average width sixty miles. In certain localities its', 12985)
('current moves at a speed of four kilometers per hour. The unchanging', 12986)
('volume of its waters is greater than that of all the world’s rivers', 12987)
('combined.', 12988)
('As discovered by Commander Maury, the true source of the Gulf Stream,', 12989)
('its starting point, if you prefer, is located in the Bay of', 12990)
('Biscay. There its waters, still weak in temperature and color, begin', 12991)
('to form. It goes down south, skirts equatorial Africa, warms its waves', 12992)
('in the rays of the Torrid Zone, crosses the Atlantic, reaches Cape São', 12993)
('Roque on the coast of Brazil, and forks into two branches, one going', 12994)
('to the Caribbean Sea for further saturation with heat particles. Then,', 12995)
('entrusted with restoring the balance between hot and cold temperatures', 12996)
('and with mixing tropical and northern waters, the Gulf Stream begins', 12997)
('to play its stabilizing role. Attaining a white heat in the Gulf of', 12998)
('Mexico, it heads north up the American coast, advances as far as', 12999)

('Davis Strait, and resumes its ocean course by going along a great', 13001)
('circle of the earth on a rhumb line; it then divides into two arms', 13002)
('near the 43rd parallel; one, helped by the northeast trade winds,', 13003)
('returns to the Bay of Biscay and the Azores; the other washes the', 13004)
('shores of Ireland and Norway with lukewarm water, goes beyond', 13005)
('Spitzbergen, where its temperature falls to 4 degrees centigrade, and', 13006)
('fashions the open sea at the pole.', 13007)
('It was on this oceanic river that the Nautilus was then', 13008)
('navigating. Leaving Old Bahama Channel, which is fourteen leagues wide', 13009)
('by 350 meters deep, the Gulf Stream moves at the rate of eight', 13010)
('kilometers per hour. Its speed steadily decreases as it advances', 13011)
('northward, and we must pray that this steadiness continues, because,', 13012)
('as experts agree, if its speed and direction were to change, the', 13013)
('climates of Europe would undergo disturbances whose consequences are', 13014)
('incalculable.', 13015)
('Near noon I was on the platform with Conseil. I shared with him the', 13016)

('sheet iron, using the monkey wrench he had with him. After likewise', 14063)
('closing the opening in the skiff, the Canadian began to unscrew the', 14064)
('nuts still bolting us to the underwater boat.', 14065)
('Suddenly a noise from the ship’s interior became audible. Voices were', 14066)
('answering each other hurriedly. What was it? Had they spotted our', 14067)
('escape? I felt Ned Land sliding a dagger into my hand.', 14068)
('“Yes,” I muttered, “we know how to die!”', 14069)
('The Canadian paused in his work. But one word twenty times repeated,', 14070)
('one dreadful word, told me the reason for the agitation spreading', 14071)
('aboard the Nautilus. We weren’t the cause of the crew’s concern.', 14072)
('“Maelstrom! Maelstrom!” they were shouting.', 14073)
('The Maelstrom! Could a more frightening name have rung in our ears', 14074)
('under more frightening circumstances? Were we lying in the dangerous', 14075)
('waterways off the Norwegian coast? Was the Nautilus being dragged into', 14076)
('this whirlpool just as the skiff was about to detach from its plating?', 14077)
('As you know, at the turn of the tide, the waters confined between the', 14078)
('Faroe and Lofoten Islands rush out with irresistible violence. They', 14079)
('form a vortex from which no ship has ever been able to', 14080)
('escape. Monstrous waves race together from every point of the', 14081)
('horizon. They form a whirlpool aptly called “the ocean’s navel,” whose', 14082)
('attracting power extends a distance of fifteen kilometers. It can suck', 14083)
('down not only ships but whales, and even polar bears from the', 14084)
('northernmost regions.', 14085)
('This was where the Nautilus had been sent accidentally—or perhaps', 14086)
('deliberately—by its captain. It was sweeping around in a spiral whose', 14087)
('radius kept growing smaller and smaller. The skiff, still attached to', 14088)
('the ship’s plating, was likewise carried around at dizzying speed. I', 14089)
('could feel us whirling. I was experiencing that accompanying nausea', 14090)
('that follows such continuous spinning motions. We were in dread, in', 14091)
('the last stages of sheer horror, our blood frozen in our veins, our', 14092)
('nerves numb, drenched in cold sweat as if from the throes of dying!', 14093)
('And what a noise around our frail skiff! What roars echoing from', 14094)
('several miles away! What crashes from the waters breaking against', 14095)
('sharp rocks on the seafloor, where the hardest objects are smashed,', 14096)
('where tree trunks are worn down and worked into “a shaggy fur,” as', 14097)
('Norwegians express it!', 14098)
('What a predicament! We were rocking frightfully. The Nautilus defended', 14099)
('itself like a human being. Its steel muscles were cracking. Sometimes', 14100)
('it stood on end, the three of us along with it!', 14101)
('“We’ve got to hold on tight,” Ned said, “and screw the nuts down', 14102)
('again! If we can stay attached to the Nautilus, we can still make it', 14103)
('. . . !”', 14104)
('He hadn’t finished speaking when a cracking sound occurred. The nuts', 14105)
('gave way, and ripped out of its socket, the skiff was hurled like a', 14106)
('stone from a sling into the midst of the vortex.', 14107)
('My head struck against an iron timber, and with this violent shock I', 14108)
('lost consciousness.', 14109)
('CHAPTER 23', 14110)
('Conclusion', 14111)
('WE COME TO the conclusion of this voyage under the seas. What happened', 14112)
('that night, how the skiff escaped from the Maelstrom’s fearsome', 14113)
('eddies, how Ned Land, Conseil, and I got out of that whirlpool, I’m', 14114)
('unable to say. But when I regained consciousness, I was lying in a', 14115)
('fisherman’s hut on one of the Lofoten Islands. My two companions, safe', 14116)
('and sound, were at my bedside clasping my hands. We embraced each', 14117)
('other heartily.', 14118)
('Just now we can’t even dream of returning to France. Travel between', 14119)
('upper Norway and the south is limited. So I have to wait for the', 14120)
('arrival of a steamboat that provides bimonthly service from North', 14121)
('Cape.', 14122)
('So it is here, among these gallant people who have taken us in, that', 14123)
('I’m reviewing my narrative of these adventures. It is accurate. Not a', 14124)
('fact has been omitted, not a detail has been exaggerated. It’s the', 14125)
('faithful record of this inconceivable expedition into an element now', 14126)
('beyond human reach, but where progress will someday make great', 14127)
('inroads.', 14128)
('Will anyone believe me? I don’t know. Ultimately it’s', 14129)
('unimportant. What I can now assert is that I’ve earned the right to', 14130)
('speak of these seas, beneath which in less than ten months, I’ve', 14131)
('cleared 20,000 leagues in this underwater tour of the world that has', 14132)
('shown me so many wonders across the Pacific, the Indian Ocean, the Red', 14133)
('Sea, the Mediterranean, the Atlantic, the southernmost and', 14134)
('northernmost seas!', 14135)
('But what happened to the Nautilus? Did it withstand the Maelstrom’s', 14136)
('clutches? Is Captain Nemo alive? Is he still under the ocean pursuing', 14137)
('his frightful program of revenge, or did he stop after that latest', 14138)
('mass execution? Will the waves someday deliver that manuscript that', 14139)
('contains his full life story? Will I finally learn the man’s name?', 14140)
('Will the nationality of the stricken warship tell us the nationality', 14141)
('of Captain Nemo?', 14142)
('I hope so. I likewise hope that his powerful submersible has defeated', 14143)
('the sea inside its most dreadful whirlpool, that the Nautilus has', 14144)
('survived where so many ships have perished! If this is the case and', 14145)
('Captain Nemo still inhabits the ocean—his adopted country—may the hate', 14146)
('be appeased in that fierce heart! May the contemplation of so many', 14147)
('wonders extinguish the spirit of vengeance in him! May the executioner', 14148)
('pass away, and the scientist continue his peaceful exploration of the', 14149)
('seas! If his destiny is strange, it’s also sublime. Haven’t I', 14150)
('encompassed it myself? Didn’t I lead ten months of this otherworldly', 14151)
('existence? Thus to that question asked 6,000 years ago in the Book of', 14152)
('Ecclesiastes—“Who can fathom the soundless depths?”—two men out of all', 14153)
('humanity have now earned the right to reply. Captain Nemo and I.', 14154)
('END OF THE SECOND PART', 14155)

('Introduction', 32)
('Folklore, legends, myths and fairy tales have followed childhood', 33)
('through the ages, for every healthy youngster has a wholesome and', 34)
('instinctive love for stories fantastic, marvelous and manifestly', 35)
('unreal. The winged fairies of Grimm and Andersen have brought more', 36)
('happiness to childish hearts than all other human creations.', 37)
('Yet the old time fairy tale, having served for generations, may now be', 38)
('classed as “historical” in the children’s library; for the time has', 39)
('come for a series of newer “wonder tales” in which the stereotyped', 40)
('genie, dwarf and fairy are eliminated, together with all the horrible', 41)
('and blood-curdling incidents devised by their authors to point a', 42)
('fearsome moral to each tale. Modern education includes morality;', 43)
('therefore the modern child seeks only entertainment in its wonder tales', 44)
('and gladly dispenses with all disagreeable incident.', 45)
('Having this thought in mind, the story of “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz”', 46)
('was written solely to please children of today. It aspires to being a', 47)
('modernized fairy tale, in which the wonderment and joy are retained and', 48)
('the heartaches and nightmares are left out.', 49)
('L. Frank Baum', 50)
('Chicago, April, 1900.', 51)
('The Wonderful Wizard of Oz', 52)
('Chapter I', 53)
('The Cyclone', 54)
('Dorothy lived in the midst of the great Kansas prairies, with Uncle', 55)
('Henry, who was a farmer, and Aunt Em, who was the farmer’s wife. Their', 56)
('house was small, for the lumber to build it had to be carried by wagon', 57)
('many miles. There were four walls, a floor and a roof, which made one', 58)
('room; and this room contained a rusty looking cookstove, a cupboard for', 59)
('the dishes, a table, three or four chairs, and the beds. Uncle Henry', 60)
('and Aunt Em had a big bed in one corner, and Dorothy a little bed in', 61)
('another corner. There was no garret at all, and no cellar—except a', 62)
('small hole dug in the ground, called a cyclone cellar, where the family', 63)
('could go in case one of those great whirlwinds arose, mighty enough to', 64)
('crush any building in its path. It was reached by a trap door in the', 65)

('hole.', 67)
('When Dorothy stood in the doorway and looked around, she could see', 68)

('and left them a sober gray; they had taken the red from her cheeks and', 79)

('could find anything to laugh at.', 85)
('Uncle Henry never laughed. He worked hard from morning till night and', 86)

('rough boots, and he looked stern and solemn, and rarely spoke.', 88)
('It was Toto that made Dorothy laugh, and saved her from growing as gray', 89)

('and the house shook so hard that she lost her footing and sat down', 115)

('The north and south winds met where the house stood, and made it the', 120)

('generally still, but the great pressure of the wind on every side of', 122)
('the house raised it up higher and higher, until it was at the very top', 123)

('Once Toto got too near the open trap door, and fell in; and at first', 133)
