('a friendly little nod, whirled around on her left heel three times, and', 318)
('straightway disappeared, much to the surprise of little Toto, who', 319)
('barked after her loudly enough when she had gone, because he had been', 320)
('afraid even to growl while she stood by.', 321)
('But Dorothy, knowing her to be a witch, had expected her to disappear', 322)
('in just that way, and was not surprised in the least.', 323)
('Chapter III', 324)
('How Dorothy Saved the Scarecrow', 325)
('When Dorothy was left alone she began to feel hungry. So she went to', 326)
('the cupboard and cut herself some bread, which she spread with butter.', 327)
('She gave some to Toto, and taking a pail from the shelf she carried it', 328)
('down to the little brook and filled it with clear, sparkling water.', 329)
('Toto ran over to the trees and began to bark at the birds sitting', 330)
('there. Dorothy went to get him, and saw such delicious fruit hanging', 331)
('from the branches that she gathered some of it, finding it just what', 332)
('she wanted to help out her breakfast.', 333)
('Then she went back to the house, and having helped herself and Toto to', 334)
('a good drink of the cool, clear water, she set about making ready for', 335)
('the journey to the City of Emeralds.', 336)
('Dorothy had only one other dress, but that happened to be clean and was', 337)
('hanging on a peg beside her bed. It was gingham, with checks of white', 338)
('and blue; and although the blue was somewhat faded with many washings,', 339)
('it was still a pretty frock. The girl washed herself carefully, dressed', 340)
('herself in the clean gingham, and tied her pink sunbonnet on her head.', 341)
('She took a little basket and filled it with bread from the cupboard,', 342)
('laying a white cloth over the top. Then she looked down at her feet and', 343)
('noticed how old and worn her shoes were.', 344)
('“They surely will never do for a long journey, Toto,” she said. And', 345)
('Toto looked up into her face with his little black eyes and wagged his', 346)
('tail to show he knew what she meant.', 347)
('At that moment Dorothy saw lying on the table the silver shoes that had', 348)
('belonged to the Witch of the East.', 349)
('“I wonder if they will fit me,” she said to Toto. “They would be just', 350)
('the thing to take a long walk in, for they could not wear out.”', 351)
('She took off her old leather shoes and tried on the silver ones, which', 352)
('fitted her as well as if they had been made for her.', 353)
('Finally she picked up her basket.', 354)
('“Come along, Toto,” she said. “We will go to the Emerald City and ask', 355)
('the Great Oz how to get back to Kansas again.”', 356)
('She closed the door, locked it, and put the key carefully in the pocket', 357)
('of her dress. And so, with Toto trotting along soberly behind her, she', 358)
('started on her journey.', 359)
('There were several roads nearby, but it did not take her long to find', 360)
('the one paved with yellow bricks. Within a short time she was walking', 361)
('briskly toward the Emerald City, her silver shoes tinkling merrily on', 362)
('the hard, yellow road-bed. The sun shone bright and the birds sang', 363)
('sweetly, and Dorothy did not feel nearly so bad as you might think a', 364)
('little girl would who had been suddenly whisked away from her own', 365)
('country and set down in the midst of a strange land.', 366)
('She was surprised, as she walked along, to see how pretty the country', 367)
('was about her. There were neat fences at the sides of the road, painted', 368)
('a dainty blue color, and beyond them were fields of grain and', 369)
('vegetables in abundance. Evidently the Munchkins were good farmers and', 370)
('able to raise large crops. Once in a while she would pass a house, and', 371)
('the people came out to look at her and bow low as she went by; for', 372)
('everyone knew she had been the means of destroying the Wicked Witch and', 373)
('setting them free from bondage. The houses of the Munchkins were', 374)
('odd-looking dwellings, for each was round, with a big dome for a roof.', 375)
('All were painted blue, for in this country of the East blue was the', 376)
('favorite color.', 377)
('Toward evening, when Dorothy was tired with her long walk and began to', 378)
('wonder where she should pass the night, she came to a house rather', 379)
('larger than the rest. On the green lawn before it many men and women', 380)
('were dancing. Five little fiddlers played as loudly as possible, and', 381)
('the people were laughing and singing, while a big table near by was', 382)
('loaded with delicious fruits and nuts, pies and cakes, and many other', 383)
('good things to eat.', 384)
('The people greeted Dorothy kindly, and invited her to supper and to', 385)
('pass the night with them; for this was the home of one of the richest', 386)
('Munchkins in the land, and his friends were gathered with him to', 387)
('celebrate their freedom from the bondage of the Wicked Witch.', 388)
('Dorothy ate a hearty supper and was waited upon by the rich Munchkin', 389)
('himself, whose name was Boq. Then she sat upon a settee and watched the', 390)
('people dance.', 391)
('When Boq saw her silver shoes he said, “You must be a great sorceress.”', 392)
('“Why?” asked the girl.', 393)
('“Because you wear silver shoes and have killed the Wicked Witch.', 394)
('Besides, you have white in your frock, and only witches and sorceresses', 395)
('wear white.”', 396)
('“My dress is blue and white checked,” said Dorothy, smoothing out the', 397)
('wrinkles in it.', 398)
('“It is kind of you to wear that,” said Boq. “Blue is the color of the', 399)
('Munchkins, and white is the witch color. So we know you are a friendly', 400)
('witch.”', 401)
('Dorothy did not know what to say to this, for all the people seemed to', 402)
('think her a witch, and she knew very well she was only an ordinary', 403)
('little girl who had come by the chance of a cyclone into a strange', 404)
('land.', 405)
('When she had tired watching the dancing, Boq led her into the house,', 406)
('where he gave her a room with a pretty bed in it. The sheets were made', 407)
('of blue cloth, and Dorothy slept soundly in them till morning, with', 408)
('Toto curled up on the blue rug beside her.', 409)
('She ate a hearty breakfast, and watched a wee Munchkin baby, who played', 410)
('with Toto and pulled his tail and crowed and laughed in a way that', 411)
('greatly amused Dorothy. Toto was a fine curiosity to all the people,', 412)
('for they had never seen a dog before.', 413)
('“How far is it to the Emerald City?” the girl asked.', 414)
('“I do not know,” answered Boq gravely, “for I have never been there. It', 415)
('is better for people to keep away from Oz, unless they have business', 416)
('with him. But it is a long way to the Emerald City, and it will take', 417)
('you many days. The country here is rich and pleasant, but you must pass', 418)
('through rough and dangerous places before you reach the end of your', 419)
('journey.”', 420)
('This worried Dorothy a little, but she knew that only the Great Oz', 421)
('could help her get to Kansas again, so she bravely resolved not to turn', 422)
('back.', 423)
('She bade her friends good-bye, and again started along the road of', 424)
('yellow brick. When she had gone several miles she thought she would', 425)
('stop to rest, and so climbed to the top of the fence beside the road', 426)
('and sat down. There was a great cornfield beyond the fence, and not far', 427)
('away she saw a Scarecrow, placed high on a pole to keep the birds from', 428)
('the ripe corn.', 429)
('Dorothy leaned her chin upon her hand and gazed thoughtfully at the', 430)
('Scarecrow. Its head was a small sack stuffed with straw, with eyes,', 431)
('nose, and mouth painted on it to represent a face. An old, pointed blue', 432)
('hat, that had belonged to some Munchkin, was perched on his head, and', 433)
('the rest of the figure was a blue suit of clothes, worn and faded,', 434)
('which had also been stuffed with straw. On the feet were some old boots', 435)
('with blue tops, such as every man wore in this country, and the figure', 436)
('was raised above the stalks of corn by means of the pole stuck up its', 437)
('back.', 438)
('While Dorothy was looking earnestly into the queer, painted face of the', 439)
('Scarecrow, she was surprised to see one of the eyes slowly wink at her.', 440)
('She thought she must have been mistaken at first, for none of the', 441)
('scarecrows in Kansas ever wink; but presently the figure nodded its', 442)
('head to her in a friendly way. Then she climbed down from the fence and', 443)
('walked up to it, while Toto ran around the pole and barked.', 444)
('“Good day,” said the Scarecrow, in a rather husky voice.', 445)
('“Did you speak?” asked the girl, in wonder.', 446)
('“Certainly,” answered the Scarecrow. “How do you do?”', 447)
('“I’m pretty well, thank you,” replied Dorothy politely. “How do you', 448)
('do?”', 449)
('“I’m not feeling well,” said the Scarecrow, with a smile, “for it is', 450)
('very tedious being perched up here night and day to scare away crows.”', 451)
('“Can’t you get down?” asked Dorothy.', 452)
('“No, for this pole is stuck up my back. If you will please take away', 453)
('the pole I shall be greatly obliged to you.”', 454)
('Dorothy reached up both arms and lifted the figure off the pole, for,', 455)
('being stuffed with straw, it was quite light.', 456)
('“Thank you very much,” said the Scarecrow, when he had been set down on', 457)
('the ground. “I feel like a new man.”', 458)
('Dorothy was puzzled at this, for it sounded queer to hear a stuffed man', 459)
('speak, and to see him bow and walk along beside her.', 460)
('“Who are you?” asked the Scarecrow when he had stretched himself and', 461)
('yawned. “And where are you going?”', 462)
('“My name is Dorothy,” said the girl, “and I am going to the Emerald', 463)
('City, to ask the Great Oz to send me back to Kansas.”', 464)
('“Where is the Emerald City?” he inquired. “And who is Oz?”', 465)
('“Why, don’t you know?” she returned, in surprise.', 466)
('“No, indeed. I don’t know anything. You see, I am stuffed, so I have no', 467)
('brains at all,” he answered sadly.', 468)
('“Oh,” said Dorothy, “I’m awfully sorry for you.”', 469)
('“Do you think,” he asked, “if I go to the Emerald City with you, that', 470)
('Oz would give me some brains?”', 471)
('“I cannot tell,” she returned, “but you may come with me, if you like.', 472)
('If Oz will not give you any brains you will be no worse off than you', 473)
('are now.”', 474)
('“That is true,” said the Scarecrow. “You see,” he continued', 475)
('confidentially, “I don’t mind my legs and arms and body being stuffed,', 476)
('because I cannot get hurt. If anyone treads on my toes or sticks a pin', 477)
('into me, it doesn’t matter, for I can’t feel it. But I do not want', 478)
('people to call me a fool, and if my head stays stuffed with straw', 479)
('instead of with brains, as yours is, how am I ever to know anything?”', 480)
('“I understand how you feel,” said the little girl, who was truly sorry', 481)
('for him. “If you will come with me I’ll ask Oz to do all he can for', 482)
('you.”', 483)
('“Thank you,” he answered gratefully.', 484)
('They walked back to the road. Dorothy helped him over the fence, and', 485)
('they started along the path of yellow brick for the Emerald City.', 486)
('Toto did not like this addition to the party at first. He smelled', 487)
('around the stuffed man as if he suspected there might be a nest of rats', 488)
('in the straw, and he often growled in an unfriendly way at the', 489)
('Scarecrow.', 490)
('“Don’t mind Toto,” said Dorothy to her new friend. “He never bites.”', 491)
('“Oh, I’m not afraid,” replied the Scarecrow. “He can’t hurt the straw.', 492)
('Do let me carry that basket for you. I shall not mind it, for I can’t', 493)
('get tired. I’ll tell you a secret,” he continued, as he walked along.', 494)
('“There is only one thing in the world I am afraid of.”', 495)
('“What is that?” asked Dorothy; “the Munchkin farmer who made you?”', 496)
('“No,” answered the Scarecrow; “it’s a lighted match.”', 497)
('Chapter IV', 498)
('The Road Through the Forest', 499)
('After a few hours the road began to be rough, and the walking grew so', 500)
('difficult that the Scarecrow often stumbled over the yellow bricks,', 501)
('which were here very uneven. Sometimes, indeed, they were broken or', 502)
('missing altogether, leaving holes that Toto jumped across and Dorothy', 503)
('walked around. As for the Scarecrow, having no brains, he walked', 504)
('straight ahead, and so stepped into the holes and fell at full length', 505)
('on the hard bricks. It never hurt him, however, and Dorothy would pick', 506)
('him up and set him upon his feet again, while he joined her in laughing', 507)
('merrily at his own mishap.', 508)
('The farms were not nearly so well cared for here as they were farther', 509)
('back. There were fewer houses and fewer fruit trees, and the farther', 510)
('they went the more dismal and lonesome the country became.', 511)
('At noon they sat down by the roadside, near a little brook, and Dorothy', 512)
('opened her basket and got out some bread. She offered a piece to the', 513)
('Scarecrow, but he refused.', 514)
('“I am never hungry,” he said, “and it is a lucky thing I am not, for my', 515)
('mouth is only painted, and if I should cut a hole in it so I could eat,', 516)
('the straw I am stuffed with would come out, and that would spoil the', 517)
('shape of my head.”', 518)
('Dorothy saw at once that this was true, so she only nodded and went on', 519)
('eating her bread.', 520)
('“Tell me something about yourself and the country you came from,” said', 521)
('the Scarecrow, when she had finished her dinner. So she told him all', 522)
('about Kansas, and how gray everything was there, and how the cyclone', 523)
('had carried her to this queer Land of Oz.', 524)
('The Scarecrow listened carefully, and said, “I cannot understand why', 525)
('you should wish to leave this beautiful country and go back to the dry,', 526)
('gray place you call Kansas.”', 527)
('“That is because you have no brains” answered the girl. “No matter how', 528)
('dreary and gray our homes are, we people of flesh and blood would', 529)
('rather live there than in any other country, be it ever so beautiful.', 530)
('There is no place like home.”', 531)
('The Scarecrow sighed.', 532)
('“Of course I cannot understand it,” he said. “If your heads were', 533)
('stuffed with straw, like mine, you would probably all live in the', 534)
('beautiful places, and then Kansas would have no people at all. It is', 535)
('fortunate for Kansas that you have brains.”', 536)
('“Won’t you tell me a story, while we are resting?” asked the child.', 537)
('The Scarecrow looked at her reproachfully, and answered:', 538)
('“My life has been so short that I really know nothing whatever. I was', 539)
('only made day before yesterday. What happened in the world before that', 540)
('time is all unknown to me. Luckily, when the farmer made my head, one', 541)
('of the first things he did was to paint my ears, so that I heard what', 542)
('was going on. There was another Munchkin with him, and the first thing', 543)
('I heard was the farmer saying, ‘How do you like those ears?’', 544)
('“‘They aren’t straight,’” answered the other.', 545)
('“‘Never mind,’” said the farmer. “‘They are ears just the same,’” which', 546)
('was true enough.', 547)
('“‘Now I’ll make the eyes,’” said the farmer. So he painted my right', 548)
('eye, and as soon as it was finished I found myself looking at him and', 549)
('at everything around me with a great deal of curiosity, for this was my', 550)
('first glimpse of the world.', 551)
('“‘That’s a rather pretty eye,’” remarked the Munchkin who was watching', 552)
('the farmer. “‘Blue paint is just the color for eyes.’', 553)
('“‘I think I’ll make the other a little bigger,’” said the farmer. And', 554)
('when the second eye was done I could see much better than before. Then', 555)
('he made my nose and my mouth. But I did not speak, because at that time', 556)
('I didn’t know what a mouth was for. I had the fun of watching them make', 557)
('my body and my arms and legs; and when they fastened on my head, at', 558)
('last, I felt very proud, for I thought I was just as good a man as', 559)
('anyone.', 560)
('“‘This fellow will scare the crows fast enough,’ said the farmer. ‘He', 561)
('looks just like a man.’', 562)
('“‘Why, he is a man,’ said the other, and I quite agreed with him. The', 563)
('farmer carried me under his arm to the cornfield, and set me up on a', 564)
('tall stick, where you found me. He and his friend soon after walked', 565)
('away and left me alone.', 566)
('“I did not like to be deserted this way. So I tried to walk after them.', 567)
('But my feet would not touch the ground, and I was forced to stay on', 568)
('that pole. It was a lonely life to lead, for I had nothing to think of,', 569)
('having been made such a little while before. Many crows and other birds', 570)
('flew into the cornfield, but as soon as they saw me they flew away', 571)
('again, thinking I was a Munchkin; and this pleased me and made me feel', 572)
('that I was quite an important person. By and by an old crow flew near', 573)
('me, and after looking at me carefully he perched upon my shoulder and', 574)
('said:', 575)
('“‘I wonder if that farmer thought to fool me in this clumsy manner. Any', 576)
('crow of sense could see that you are only stuffed with straw.’ Then he', 577)
('hopped down at my feet and ate all the corn he wanted. The other birds,', 578)
('seeing he was not harmed by me, came to eat the corn too, so in a short', 579)
('time there was a great flock of them about me.', 580)
('“I felt sad at this, for it showed I was not such a good Scarecrow', 581)
('after all; but the old crow comforted me, saying, ‘If you only had', 582)
('brains in your head you would be as good a man as any of them, and a', 583)
('better man than some of them. Brains are the only things worth having', 584)
('in this world, no matter whether one is a crow or a man.’', 585)
('“After the crows had gone I thought this over, and decided I would try', 586)
('hard to get some brains. By good luck you came along and pulled me off', 587)
('the stake, and from what you say I am sure the Great Oz will give me', 588)
('brains as soon as we get to the Emerald City.”', 589)
('“I hope so,” said Dorothy earnestly, “since you seem anxious to have', 590)
('them.”', 591)
('“Oh, yes; I am anxious,” returned the Scarecrow. “It is such an', 592)
('uncomfortable feeling to know one is a fool.”', 593)
('“Well,” said the girl, “let us go.” And she handed the basket to the', 594)
('Scarecrow.', 595)
('There were no fences at all by the roadside now, and the land was rough', 596)
('and untilled. Toward evening they came to a great forest, where the', 597)
('trees grew so big and close together that their branches met over the', 598)
('road of yellow brick. It was almost dark under the trees, for the', 599)
('branches shut out the daylight; but the travelers did not stop, and', 600)
('went on into the forest.', 601)
('“If this road goes in, it must come out,” said the Scarecrow, “and as', 602)
('the Emerald City is at the other end of the road, we must go wherever', 603)
('it leads us.”', 604)
('“Anyone would know that,” said Dorothy.', 605)
('“Certainly; that is why I know it,” returned the Scarecrow. “If it', 606)
('required brains to figure it out, I never should have said it.”', 607)
('After an hour or so the light faded away, and they found themselves', 608)
('stumbling along in the darkness. Dorothy could not see at all, but Toto', 609)
('could, for some dogs see very well in the dark; and the Scarecrow', 610)
('declared he could see as well as by day. So she took hold of his arm', 611)
('and managed to get along fairly well.', 612)
('“If you see any house, or any place where we can pass the night,” she', 613)
('said, “you must tell me; for it is very uncomfortable walking in the', 614)
('dark.”', 615)
('Soon after the Scarecrow stopped.', 616)
('“I see a little cottage at the right of us,” he said, “built of logs', 617)
('and branches. Shall we go there?”', 618)
('“Yes, indeed,” answered the child. “I am all tired out.”', 619)
('So the Scarecrow led her through the trees until they reached the', 620)
('cottage, and Dorothy entered and found a bed of dried leaves in one', 621)
('corner. She lay down at once, and with Toto beside her soon fell into a', 622)
('sound sleep. The Scarecrow, who was never tired, stood up in another', 623)
('corner and waited patiently until morning came.', 624)
('Chapter V', 625)
('The Rescue of the Tin Woodman', 626)
('When Dorothy awoke the sun was shining through the trees and Toto had', 627)
('long been out chasing birds around him and squirrels. She sat up and', 628)
('looked around her. There was the Scarecrow, still standing patiently in', 629)
('his corner, waiting for her.', 630)
('“We must go and search for water,” she said to him.', 631)
('“Why do you want water?” he asked.', 632)
('“To wash my face clean after the dust of the road, and to drink, so the', 633)
('dry bread will not stick in my throat.”', 634)
('“It must be inconvenient to be made of flesh,” said the Scarecrow', 635)
('thoughtfully, “for you must sleep, and eat and drink. However, you have', 636)
('brains, and it is worth a lot of bother to be able to think properly.”', 637)
('They left the cottage and walked through the trees until they found a', 638)
('little spring of clear water, where Dorothy drank and bathed and ate', 639)
('her breakfast. She saw there was not much bread left in the basket, and', 640)
('the girl was thankful the Scarecrow did not have to eat anything, for', 641)
('there was scarcely enough for herself and Toto for the day.', 642)
('When she had finished her meal, and was about to go back to the road of', 643)
('yellow brick, she was startled to hear a deep groan near by.', 644)
('“What was that?” she asked timidly.', 645)
('“I cannot imagine,” replied the Scarecrow; “but we can go and see.”', 646)
('Just then another groan reached their ears, and the sound seemed to', 647)
('come from behind them. They turned and walked through the forest a few', 648)
('steps, when Dorothy discovered something shining in a ray of sunshine', 649)
('that fell between the trees. She ran to the place and then stopped', 650)
('short, with a little cry of surprise.', 651)
('One of the big trees had been partly chopped through, and standing', 652)
('beside it, with an uplifted axe in his hands, was a man made entirely', 653)
('of tin. His head and arms and legs were jointed upon his body, but he', 654)
('stood perfectly motionless, as if he could not stir at all.', 655)
('Dorothy looked at him in amazement, and so did the Scarecrow, while', 656)
('Toto barked sharply and made a snap at the tin legs, which hurt his', 657)
('teeth.', 658)
('“Did you groan?” asked Dorothy.', 659)
('“Yes,” answered the tin man, “I did. I’ve been groaning for more than a', 660)
('year, and no one has ever heard me before or come to help me.”', 661)
('“What can I do for you?” she inquired softly, for she was moved by the', 662)
('sad voice in which the man spoke.', 663)
('“Get an oil-can and oil my joints,” he answered. “They are rusted so', 664)
('badly that I cannot move them at all; if I am well oiled I shall soon', 665)
('be all right again. You will find an oil-can on a shelf in my cottage.”', 666)
('Dorothy at once ran back to the cottage and found the oil-can, and then', 667)
('she returned and asked anxiously, “Where are your joints?”', 668)
('“Oil my neck, first,” replied the Tin Woodman. So she oiled it, and as', 669)
('it was quite badly rusted the Scarecrow took hold of the tin head and', 670)
('moved it gently from side to side until it worked freely, and then the', 671)
('man could turn it himself.', 672)
('“Now oil the joints in my arms,” he said. And Dorothy oiled them and', 673)
('the Scarecrow bent them carefully until they were quite free from rust', 674)
('and as good as new.', 675)
('The Tin Woodman gave a sigh of satisfaction and lowered his axe, which', 676)
('he leaned against the tree.', 677)
('“This is a great comfort,” he said. “I have been holding that axe in', 678)
('the air ever since I rusted, and I’m glad to be able to put it down at', 679)
('last. Now, if you will oil the joints of my legs, I shall be all right', 680)
('once more.”', 681)
('So they oiled his legs until he could move them freely; and he thanked', 682)
('them again and again for his release, for he seemed a very polite', 683)
('creature, and very grateful.', 684)
('“I might have stood there always if you had not come along,” he said;', 685)
('“so you have certainly saved my life. How did you happen to be here?”', 686)
('“We are on our way to the Emerald City to see the Great Oz,” she', 687)
('answered, “and we stopped at your cottage to pass the night.”', 688)
('“Why do you wish to see Oz?” he asked.', 689)
('“I want him to send me back to Kansas, and the Scarecrow wants him to', 690)
('put a few brains into his head,” she replied.', 691)
('The Tin Woodman appeared to think deeply for a moment. Then he said:', 692)
('“Do you suppose Oz could give me a heart?”', 693)
('“Why, I guess so,” Dorothy answered. “It would be as easy as to give', 694)
('the Scarecrow brains.”', 695)
('“True,” the Tin Woodman returned. “So, if you will allow me to join', 696)
('your party, I will also go to the Emerald City and ask Oz to help me.”', 697)
('“Come along,” said the Scarecrow heartily, and Dorothy added that she', 698)
('would be pleased to have his company. So the Tin Woodman shouldered his', 699)
('axe and they all passed through the forest until they came to the road', 700)
('that was paved with yellow brick.', 701)
('The Tin Woodman had asked Dorothy to put the oil-can in her basket.', 702)
('“For,” he said, “if I should get caught in the rain, and rust again, I', 703)
('would need the oil-can badly.”', 704)
('It was a bit of good luck to have their new comrade join the party, for', 705)
('soon after they had begun their journey again they came to a place', 706)
('where the trees and branches grew so thick over the road that the', 707)
('travelers could not pass. But the Tin Woodman set to work with his axe', 708)
('and chopped so well that soon he cleared a passage for the entire', 709)
('party.', 710)
('Dorothy was thinking so earnestly as they walked along that she did not', 711)
('notice when the Scarecrow stumbled into a hole and rolled over to the', 712)
('side of the road. Indeed he was obliged to call to her to help him up', 713)
('again.', 714)
('“Why didn’t you walk around the hole?” asked the Tin Woodman.', 715)
('“I don’t know enough,” replied the Scarecrow cheerfully. “My head is', 716)
('stuffed with straw, you know, and that is why I am going to Oz to ask', 717)
('him for some brains.”', 718)
('“Oh, I see,” said the Tin Woodman. “But, after all, brains are not the', 719)
('best things in the world.”', 720)
('“Have you any?” inquired the Scarecrow.', 721)
('“No, my head is quite empty,” answered the Woodman. “But once I had', 722)
('brains, and a heart also; so, having tried them both, I should much', 723)
('rather have a heart.”', 724)
('“And why is that?” asked the Scarecrow.', 725)
('“I will tell you my story, and then you will know.”', 726)
('So, while they were walking through the forest, the Tin Woodman told', 727)
('the following story:', 728)
('“I was born the son of a woodman who chopped down trees in the forest', 729)
('and sold the wood for a living. When I grew up, I too became a', 730)
('woodchopper, and after my father died I took care of my old mother as', 731)
('long as she lived. Then I made up my mind that instead of living alone', 732)
('I would marry, so that I might not become lonely.', 733)
('“There was one of the Munchkin girls who was so beautiful that I soon', 734)
('grew to love her with all my heart. She, on her part, promised to marry', 735)
('me as soon as I could earn enough money to build a better house for', 736)
('her; so I set to work harder than ever. But the girl lived with an old', 737)
('woman who did not want her to marry anyone, for she was so lazy she', 738)
('wished the girl to remain with her and do the cooking and the', 739)
('housework. So the old woman went to the Wicked Witch of the East, and', 740)
('promised her two sheep and a cow if she would prevent the marriage.', 741)
('Thereupon the Wicked Witch enchanted my axe, and when I was chopping', 742)
('away at my best one day, for I was anxious to get the new house and my', 743)
('wife as soon as possible, the axe slipped all at once and cut off my', 744)
('left leg.', 745)
('“This at first seemed a great misfortune, for I knew a one-legged man', 746)
('could not do very well as a wood-chopper. So I went to a tinsmith and', 747)
('had him make me a new leg out of tin. The leg worked very well, once I', 748)
('was used to it. But my action angered the Wicked Witch of the East, for', 749)
('she had promised the old woman I should not marry the pretty Munchkin', 750)
('girl. When I began chopping again, my axe slipped and cut off my right', 751)
('leg. Again I went to the tinsmith, and again he made me a leg out of', 752)
('tin. After this the enchanted axe cut off my arms, one after the other;', 753)
('but, nothing daunted, I had them replaced with tin ones. The Wicked', 754)
('Witch then made the axe slip and cut off my head, and at first I', 755)
('thought that was the end of me. But the tinsmith happened to come', 756)
('along, and he made me a new head out of tin.', 757)
('“I thought I had beaten the Wicked Witch then, and I worked harder than', 758)
('ever; but I little knew how cruel my enemy could be. She thought of a', 759)
('new way to kill my love for the beautiful Munchkin maiden, and made my', 760)
('axe slip again, so that it cut right through my body, splitting me into', 761)
('two halves. Once more the tinsmith came to my help and made me a body', 762)
('of tin, fastening my tin arms and legs and head to it, by means of', 763)
('joints, so that I could move around as well as ever. But, alas! I had', 764)
('now no heart, so that I lost all my love for the Munchkin girl, and did', 765)
('not care whether I married her or not. I suppose she is still living', 766)
('with the old woman, waiting for me to come after her.', 767)
('“My body shone so brightly in the sun that I felt very proud of it and', 768)
('it did not matter now if my axe slipped, for it could not cut me. There', 769)
('was only one danger—that my joints would rust; but I kept an oil-can in', 770)
('my cottage and took care to oil myself whenever I needed it. However,', 771)
('there came a day when I forgot to do this, and, being caught in a', 772)
('rainstorm, before I thought of the danger my joints had rusted, and I', 773)
('was left to stand in the woods until you came to help me. It was a', 774)
('terrible thing to undergo, but during the year I stood there I had time', 775)
('to think that the greatest loss I had known was the loss of my heart.', 776)
('While I was in love I was the happiest man on earth; but no one can', 777)
('love who has not a heart, and so I am resolved to ask Oz to give me', 778)
('one. If he does, I will go back to the Munchkin maiden and marry her.”', 779)
('Both Dorothy and the Scarecrow had been greatly interested in the story', 780)
('of the Tin Woodman, and now they knew why he was so anxious to get a', 781)
('new heart.', 782)
('“All the same,” said the Scarecrow, “I shall ask for brains instead of', 783)
('a heart; for a fool would not know what to do with a heart if he had', 784)
('one.”', 785)
('“I shall take the heart,” returned the Tin Woodman; “for brains do not', 786)
('make one happy, and happiness is the best thing in the world.”', 787)
('Dorothy did not say anything, for she was puzzled to know which of her', 788)
('two friends was right, and she decided if she could only get back to', 789)
('Kansas and Aunt Em, it did not matter so much whether the Woodman had', 790)
('no brains and the Scarecrow no heart, or each got what he wanted.', 791)
('What worried her most was that the bread was nearly gone, and another', 792)
('meal for herself and Toto would empty the basket. To be sure, neither', 793)
('the Woodman nor the Scarecrow ever ate anything, but she was not made', 794)
('of tin nor straw, and could not live unless she was fed.', 795)
('Chapter VI', 796)
('The Cowardly Lion', 797)
('All this time Dorothy and her companions had been walking through the', 798)

('much covered by dried branches and dead leaves from the trees, and the', 800)

('“That’s why he nearly blunted my claws,” said the Lion. “When they', 849)

('Dorothy.', 888)

('beetle that was crawling along the road, and killed the poor little', 908)

('Thereafter he walked very carefully, with his eyes on the road, and', 923)
('when he saw a tiny ant toiling by he would step over it, so as not to', 924)
('harm it. The Tin Woodman knew very well he had no heart, and therefore', 925)
('he took great care never to be cruel or unkind to anything.', 926)
('“You people with hearts,” he said, “have something to guide you, and', 927)

('careful. When Oz gives me a heart of course I needn’t mind so much.”', 929)
('Chapter VII', 930)
('The Journey to the Great Oz', 931)
('They were obliged to camp out that night under a large tree in the', 932)

('covering to protect them from the dew, and the Tin Woodman chopped a', 934)

('Chapter VIII', 1083)
('The Deadly Poppy Field', 1084)
('Our little party of travelers awakened the next morning refreshed and', 1085)
('full of hope, and Dorothy breakfasted like a princess off peaches and', 1086)
('plums from the trees beside the river. Behind them was the dark forest', 1087)
('they had passed safely through, although they had suffered many', 1088)
('discouragements; but before them was a lovely, sunny country that', 1089)
('seemed to beckon them on to the Emerald City.', 1090)
('To be sure, the broad river now cut them off from this beautiful land.', 1091)
('But the raft was nearly done, and after the Tin Woodman had cut a few', 1092)
